newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RUGBY UNION-ENGLAND TEST RULED OUT, SAYS ARU.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-ENGLAND TEST RULED OUT, SAYS ARU.

text.p: The Australian Rugby Union (ARU)
said on Monday the Wallabies would definitely not play a test
against England during their forthcoming tour of Europe but
would still go ahead with a match against Wales.
ARU spokesman Greg Thomas said attempts to resolve a dispute
over the possibility of adding a test against England to the
Wallabies' eight-week, 13-match tour had failed.
"The (British) Home Unions reiterated it was impossible to
include an England test this time around," Thomas said.
ARU delegate Dick McGruther attended an International Rugby
Board (IRB) meeting in Rome at the weekend but was unable to win
over his counterparts in the Home Union Tour Committee (HUTC).
"The ARU are very disappointed at the outcome," Thomas said.
"We tried every avenue we could and we are still baffled by the
attitude of the Home Unions."
Australia had earlier threatened to scrap their test against
Wales at Cardiff Arms Park on December 1 if their request for a
match against England was rejected.
The Wales test was added to the Wallabies' itinerary at the
request of the Welsh union. Australia's request for an England
test set off a dispute over dates, with the HUTC refusing to
reschedule a match against the Barbarians at Twickenham on
December 7 and Australia rejecting two midweek dates.
Thomas said the ARU had decided to go ahead with the Wales
test despite the disappointment of being denied their first
"Grand Slam" against the four Home Unions of England, Ireland,
Scotland and Wales since 1984.
"We are committed to the Wales test, we agreed to it,"
Thomas said.
"Our board decided we didn't want to be seen to be
dishonouring a test. It would have been a retrograde step for us
to turn Wales down after England had turned us down," he said.
Thomas said the ARU would now ask for an unspecified
percentage of the gate-takings from the Barbarians match to
compensate for the loss of between A$600,000-700,000
($480,000-560,000) they said they would have received from an
England test.
Australia and England agreed last August to play each other
twice a year from 1997 until at least 2003. Thomas said the next
possible year for a "Grand Slam" would be 2000.
